title: oxford college dean accused mad unfit govern
story: The Dean of an Oxford college will face a medical assessment after he was accused of being “mad and unfit to govern” in the latest attempt by dons to oust him, his supporters claim.The Very Rev Martyn Percy, who presides over Christ Church college and cathedral, has been embroiled in a four-year row with fellow Oxford dons over his tenure.He has battled to keep his role, despite being cleared by an independent tribunal for conduct of immoral, scandalous or disgraceful nature, and the Charity Commission raising concerns over whether pursuing the dispute is a responsible use of the college's resources.He has also faced allegations of sexual harrassment, prompting a police and church investigation which have both been concluded with no further action.However, now the college has alerted the dean to a “notice of motion” ahead of a crunch meeting on Friday to determine whether he is mentally fit to govern.The  has seen a copy of the summons which states that the college’s governing body will “determine whether or not the dean’s removal on medical grounds should be considered by a medical board”.A statute in the Christ Church governance states that figures can be removed on grounds of mental incapacitation. However, the dean’s supporters claim that this loophole is being “exploited” in a bid to remove him.The mental incapacitation clause was added in a redraft of the college's statute in 2011, but a bylaw dating from August 2021 enabled other members of the governing body - not just the dean - to initiate action on medical grounds.One supporter, who is close to the case and who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: “Everyone in Oxford knows what this is about. A few people on the Christ Church governing body are determined to get rid of their dean at any cost.“They are frustrated because the Charity Commission is not prepared to let them spend vast amounts on a trumped-up tribunal. So now they are trying to declare that he is mad. I can assure you that Martyn Percy is not mad.“Anyone who has been to one of his recent lectures or read his recent book will know that he has one of the sharpest minds in academia.”The college has admitted that to date it has spent more than £1million in legal and PR costs in its 2019 attempt to oust the dean. However, the final figure is expected to be far higher.According to the summons document, Prof Lindsay Judson, the senior ex-censor and philosophy tutor, has “considered the matter very carefully and having taken legal and medical advice”, has concluded that “the dean’s condition or any mental or physical quality affecting him is such as substantially to interfere with the performance of his duties”.As a result, he is “obliged to consider the removal of the dean” in accordance with college statutes, and that “the dean’s removal on medical grounds should be considered and therefore that the case should be forwarded to a medical board”.Prof Judson, who signed off the summons, has been involved in previous proceedings regarding the dean. However, the document states that the professor “does not believe that he has a conflict of interest” in any part of the process.It also sets out that a special meeting of the governing body will be convened to consider the matter regarding the dean, and that one of its members - who “shall have some experience of the mental or physical incapacity apparently affecting” him - will be nominated to sit on a board.The governing body will also get to decide upon the two medically-qualified people to act as chairmen of the board.In contrast, the dean will only be allowed to nominate one person to sit on this board to decide whether or not he is mentally incapacitated. However, if he fails to nominate someone “reasonably expeditiously”, Prof Judson will nominate someone for him.The second ongoing tribunal is the latest effort to force out the dean, and follows an alleged incident of sexual harassment in Christ Church Cathedral in October.Thames Valley Police said it had conducted a thorough investigation into the matter at the time, adding: Our investigation has now concluded and the matter has been filed pending further information coming to light.However, the college set up its own internal probe into the incident and is now preparing to use it as the basis to remove him from his post.Allies of the dean claimed it is certainly not a safeguarding issue but part of a long-running persecution of him by other senior dons which has become a vendetta .When approached for comment, a spokesperson for the college said that there were “serious inaccuracies” in the claims. However, they refused to clarify what the inaccuracies were.The spokesperson added: “You will understand that we have a duty of care to the dean as we do with all staff and students at Christ Church, and so we are unable to make any comment on what is a sensitive HR matter.”More from NewsCovid latest news: Having coronavirus in past six months leaves you &#39relatively well protected&#39 from omicronFull list of Tory rebels who opposed No 10&#39s Covid pass planCovid alert levels explained: What Level 4 means for you as omicron cases riseCovid Plan B: How it will affect your Christmas plansReading fire: Man arrested on suspicion of murder and arson as &#39number of people unaccounted for&#39More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: bbcs younger journalists do not understand impartiality former
story: Younger journalists do not understand impartiality and confuse it with “social justice”, former BBC editors have warned.A generation that has grown up with social media believes that being impartial and saying what they think is right are the same things.Giving evidence to a House of Lords committee, Roger Mosey, the former head of BBC Television News, said: “Some younger journalists don’t understand it in the way it was classically imbued into BBC journalists over the years.”Richard Sambrook, former head of newsgathering at the corporation, is now a professor of journalism and said his students don’t see impartiality in the same way that older generations do.“I talked to students about impartiality… and they may say, ‘Well, fairness is about social justice.’ You have to try to reframe the argument. With identity politics, they have a very different concept of what is right,” he said.“We’re in a culture of calling things out. They are a generation who do not see it in quite the same way.”Sarah Sands, the former editor of Radio 4’s Today programme, said the BBC’s culture of turning news presenters into celebrities could be a threat to impartiality.She told the committee: The BBC is built on this fault line between public service news and entertainment - both valid, but there is a conflict as the BBC makes different demands on its presenters to be warmer, more accessible, to reveal more of themselves.“You have to be slightly careful of that line, and that’s when it gets into things like social media, because the point of social media is to win personal popularity and that starts to distort the way you behave.”She praised Lyse Doucet, the BBC’s chief international correspondent, as an example of a journalist who has spent a career reporting from the world’s troublespots.But she said the corporation placed more importance on news presenters who can branch out into entertainment.“To me, reporting is the noblest of all journalistic trades and I was always sorry that there was this hierarchy that a reporter is good, a presenter is better, and a presenter who could get onto Strictly is the tops.“That seems to be a pity because, actually, I think there is something rather marvellous about that sober, factual reporting,” Sands said.BBC journalists who have appeared on Strictly include Dan Walker, recently voted out of this year’s series, and Naga Munchetty, who appeared in the 2016 show.More from NewsCovid latest news: Having coronavirus in past six months leaves you &#39relatively well protected&#39 from omicronCovid alert levels explained: What Level 4 means for you as omicron cases riseCovid Plan B: How it will affect your Christmas plansReading fire: Man arrested on suspicion of murder and arson as &#39number of people unaccounted for&#39&#39More than 300&#39 trapped in Hong Kong skyscraper after fireMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: closing schools would carry heavy political price
story: Consequently, there was strong public support for quite radical “catch-up” policies from the Department for Education – for example, to extend the school day and to provide free hours for students with academic tutors.Furthermore, polling we conducted in February 2021 on mental health revealed a similar picture of deep parental and public concern. Nearly a third of parents of children under-18 said they were worried about their children’s mental health – and parents said they were badly struggling managing home schooling and their working lives. Home schooling mostly fell upon mothers, with women reporting much greater stress levels than men.For parents across the country, the relief of children going back to the classroom was extreme. Parents saw their children revert to their happy selves and the burden of home schooling was lifted they will be desperate to avoid a return to those terrible weeks.Second, the economy has deteriorated. Home schooling destroys productivity and, for many, especially the self-employed, wipes out their earnings. Since schools were last closed, the Government has announced higher taxes, and bills have risen amid new inflationary pressures. Home schooling children was stressful enough a year ago this time, many parents are going to be wondering how they will make ends meet while logging on to Zoom lessons.Third, we are in a post-vaccination environment. A year ago, people bought the need for school closures to some extent because nobody had been vaccinated – and the prospect of new vaccines gave everyone hope that these closures would be a temporary one-off. This time, most of the country has been vaccinated but we seem to be heading back to square one. People will be wondering whether this is going to be an annual occurrence there will be a great deal more weariness among parents and the public.More from NewsCovid latest news: Having coronavirus in past six months leaves you &#39relatively well protected&#39 from omicronFull list of Tory rebels who opposed No 10&#39s Covid pass planCovid alert levels explained: What Level 4 means for you as omicron cases riseCovid Plan B: How it will affect your Christmas plansReading fire: Man arrested on suspicion of murder and arson as &#39number of people unaccounted for&#39More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: wednesday morning uk news briefing todays top headlines telegraph
story: In the end, the rebellion was more devastating than had been predicted. Boris Johnson suffered the worst parliamentary revolt of his premiership last night after scores of Conservative MPs ignored a personal plea to support the introduction of Covid passports. Almost 100 Tories - close to half of the party's backbenchers - voted against legally requiring events with large crowds to check attendees for proof of vaccination or a negative test. How did your MP vote? Use our interactive search tool to find out - and see a full list of Tory rebels. Covid passports, part of the Prime Minister's Plan B restrictions, passed only thanks to Labour support. Parliamentary Sketchwriter Tim Stanley watched as the scale of the revolt unfolded. But Allison Pearson says the MPs are not rebels, but true Conservatives. The scale of the rebellion raises fresh questions about the depth of support for Mr Johnson's leadership.Meanwhile, NHS Test and Trace has told pharmacies that it cannot deliver any extra rapid Covid tests despite entire cities running out by lunchtime yesterday.The  can disclose that, during an emergency meeting, officials claimed it was not possible logistically to increase supplies to pharmacies. Sajid Javid, the Health Secretary, has advised anyone planning to mix with friends and family to take a lateral flow test beforehand to avoid catching or spreading the omicron strain. Read about the emergence of new symptoms. In other developments:It is the nightmare before Christmas. A grim deadline for businesses has passed by largely unnoticed. Guidelines rule that people who show symptoms and later test positive for coronavirus must isolate for 10 days. From this morning, that period now breaches Christmas Day - meaning those forced to quarantine will lose any remaining opportunity to buy presents on the high street or visit pubs. As Matt Oliver reports, it has prompted warnings of a lockdown by stealth, where retail, hospitality and leisure businesses remain open but are powerless as confusing and sometimes contradictory official diktats drain consumers' confidence.When major crises erupt and the Prime Minister assembles his top team, real-time data has traditionally been difficult to pipe in. Like laptops and phones, technology has tended to be left outside the room as a security precaution. All that has changed with the creation of the National Situation Centre, which allows the latest data to be beamed into the highest-level meetings dealing with emergencies. Deputy Political Editor Lucy Fisher is the first journalist to see the £9m White House-style facility, nicknamed SitCen, which lies at the heart of the Cabinet Office in Whitehall. Read her report and see pictures from inside.View Matt's latest cartoon as he looks at the dilemma facing households this party season.Social services missed 'blindingly obvious' signs | Lockdown failures put a toddler in the hands of barbaric killers in a deeply disturbing case which should leave council leaders hanging their heads in shame. Crime Correspondent Martin Evans has the full background on how the role of social services departments is once again under scrutiny after the death of Star Hobson, a 16-month-old girl from West Yorkshire.An Antarctic glacier the size of Britain could shatter like a car windscreen in the next five to 10 years, causing a huge rise in global sea levels. Thwaites Glacier, in the western Antarctic, is the widest on Earth at 80 miles across and a giant section of it at risk of breaking off and releasing hundreds of billions of tonnes of ice into the sea. As Jamie Johnson reports, its break up would see sea levels rise by more than 2ft.Premier League footballers will undergo more intense Covid testing from today with lateral flow tests to be taken at training grounds before they get out of their cars in an effort to fight the latest spike in infections. The league's 20 clubs were updated by the executive team on measures around the omicron outbreak that led to two games being postponed and 42 positive tests among players and staff last week. Last night, Man City destroyed Leeds United 7-0 to extend their lead to four points.Rishi Sunak must be ready to bring back the furlough scheme to save shops and restaurants, the International Monetary Fund has warned, amid the threat of further economic restrictions. Officials are reportedly considering a Plan C, including mandating table service in pubs. The financial stability watchdog said the Chancellor should prepare to reintroduce measures to limit the economic damage from any new rules. Yet Jeremy Warner says the call only reinforces the sense of blind panic.Cheese, onion and potato pie | It can be hard to make a vegetable dish the main deal, but pies are your best bet, says Diana Henry. View the recipe. For more, try our Cookbook newsletter.Fancy an easy city break this winter? | Some of Europe's most fascinating cities are within an easy train ride from London. And if you are heading to the Continent, you can take the pre-departure test required to return to Britain before you have even left home. William Cook has selected five trips that take advantage of the testing loophole.Truth about IQ | New research suggests that there is not as wide a gap between the boffin and the layman as first thought. Guy Kelly explains why intelligence tests are as complicated as rocket science.If you want to receive twice-daily briefings like this by email, sign up to the Front Page newsletter here. title: at last tories face up
story: At last Tories face up to fact charlatan Johnson is unfit to lead a great countryCharlatan Boris Johnsons power is clearly seeping away after tonights revolt by almost  Tory MPs - the writing is clearly on the wall for the worst Prime Minister this side of the Second World WarBoris Johnson is the worst Prime Minister this side of the Second World War Image: Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Dec | commentsBoris Johnson is haemorrhaging authority after a record, thumping rebellion by almost  Conservative MPs. He isn’t quite yet in office without power but power is clearly seeping away and the charlatan increasingly isolated in that office. Led by Keir Starmer, Labour looked like an alternative government in the making as they voted to save the Covid Plan B safety measures, even as Johnson’s reign crumbles. Two years after securing an -seat majority, the writing’s clearly on the wall for Johnson. His looming demise will make him more desperate than ever to cling on North Shropshire, a Tory citadel, in tomorrow’s by-election. Britain’s tragedy is to have in Downing Street during a cataclysmic pandemic, with a new virus mutation rampant, the worst Prime Minister this side of the Second World War. Johnson is unfit to lead a great country. At last, Conservative MPs are facing up to that. Take the photo politan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick is welcome to use our photograph of Tory London Mayoral candidate Shaun Bailey at a Covid rule-breaking crowded party in Conservative HQ. She can also study our picture of Boris Johnson at a Downing Street quiz, flanked by a colleague garlanded with tinsel, to gather evidence that the rulers did not follow the rules they imposed on the ruled. The stonewalling police chief’s refusal to investigate what went on at the heart of Government late last year is itself becoming a scandal. Tens of thousands of people were fined for breaching restrictions. We must all be equal before the law and the law must treat us all equally. Number’s up Crime didn’t pay for two men who bought a National Lottery scratchcard using a stolen debit card, then tried to claim the £million jackpot. The dodgy pair’s unlucky number is  – the number of months each was jailed. title: extraordinary image shows raucous xmas
story: Exclusive: Extraordinary image shows raucous Xmas party thrown by Tory aides in lockdown breachOur image shows  people crowded together in a room in the Tories Westminster HQ for an event organised by Shaun Bailey’s mayoral campaign - Mr Bailey tonight quit as chair of the London Assembly’s police and crime committee after being approached by the Mirror and Nick Candyare seen at the party at Tory HQ" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _PARTY.jpg" width"" "" Shaun Baileyand billionaire Tory donor Nick Candyare seen at the party at HQByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments An extraordinary image has emerged of a “raucous” Christmas party thrown by Tory aides during coronavirus restrictions last Christmas. It shows  people crowded together - in blatant breach of lockdown rules - in a medium-sized room in the party’s Westminster HQ.Some of the group are shown wearing paper hats while one is sporting a House of Commons Christmas jumper.The event, organised by top Tory Shaun Bailey ’s mayoral campaign, took place on December  last year when London was in Tier .After he was approached by the Mirror tonight, Mr Bailey dramatically quit as chair of the London Assembly’s police and crime committee.  The image also shows several guests - including billionaire Tory donor Nick Candy - raising glasses of wine while a catered buffet features prominently. One of the revellers was a senior figure on Boris Johnsonaposs leadership election campaign. It emerged last week that Tory staff danced and drank wine late into the night and revellers damaged a door at what was described as a “raucous” event. At the time, the capital was in Tier  restrictions which banned any social mixing between households indoors.The party took place the day before the No  festive quiz, where Boris Johnson was pictured as quizmaster, and four days ahead of the Downing Street Christmas bash.Hours before the party then health secretary Matt Hancock announced that the capital would move into tougher Tier  restrictions. Tory insiders suggested tonight that party chairman Oliver Dowden was appalled by the photograph of the festive event. The Conservatives have said that “formal disciplinary action” had been taken against four CCHQ staff seconded to the campaign. A spokesman said: “Senior CCHQ staff became aware of an unauthorised social gathering in the basement of [CCHQ] organised by the Bailey campaign on the evening of th December. “Formal disciplinary action was taken against the four CCHQ staff who were seconded to the Bailey campaign.” Scotland Yard has until now refused to investigate the Christmas gatherings citing a lack of evidence.  Labour deputy leader Angela Rayner said: “This is damning new evidence of a party, with a buffet, drinks, Christmas attire and absolutely no social distancing held at Conservative Party HQ.“Shaun Bailey is an elected official that is clearly breaking Covid regulations in this photo and encouraging the same of his staff. “Whilst everyone  was making sacrices to keep their community safe, the chair of the Police and Crime committee in the Greater London Authority was partying. “His position as chair was untenable and he knew that.” Mr Bailey, who does not drink alcohol, is said to have left the party early in the evening, shortly after the picture was taken. A Shaun Bailey campaign spokesperson said: “On the evening of  December , at the end of the working day, the campaign hosted a post-work event to thank campaign staff for their efforts over the course of they year. “This was a serious error of judgement and we fully accept that gathering like this as that time was wrong and apologise unreservedly”. A spokesperson for Mr Candy said: “Nick Candy attended the office of the Shaun Bailey campaign for an end of year review on  December .He gave a short thank you speech to the team and spent some time with Shaun Bailey to discuss campaign matters before leaving shortly afterwards.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyGreater London AuthorityShaun BaileyBoris JohnsonCrimePoliticsCoronavirusDowning Street Christmas PartyTory Government" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: fifteen minute wait after pfizer
story: Fteen-minute wait after Pfizer Covid jab scrapped to ramp up , more boostersDepartment of Health and Social Care says chief medical officers have decided the -minute wait after Pfizer Covid jabs will "cause more harm than it averts" " content"https:i-prod.dailyrecord incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" The US approved Pfizer jags for kids aged five to  in early November Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByTom Ambrose:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments The -minute wait for patients after theyaposve been jabbed with the Pfizer Covid jab has been scrapped by NHS England so more booster jabs can be administered.It is estimated that getting rid of the additional wait time after being jabbed will increase NHS capacity by almost a quarter , according to reports. In a statement, the Department of Health and Social Caresaid the -minute wait time is likely to cause more harm than it averts. It said: The Chief Medical Officersof the UK and lead Deputy Chief Medical Officersfor vaccines have considered whether, in the light of the very considerable need to speed up vaccination and boosting in response to Omicron iant, the -minute wait for some mRNA Covid- vaccines should be suspended.  Their view, having considered the views of the Covid- Vaccine Benefit-Risk Expert Working Group , NHS planners and others is that with the low rates of anaphylaxis, in the context of the considerable need for people to be boosted or vaccinated, the -minute wait after a vaccination with mRNA vaccine will cause more harm than it can avert because it will signicantly reduce the number of people who can be vaccinated over a short period of time.The -minute wait should therefore be suspended for first, second and homologous or heterologous boost vaccinations with mRNA vaccine given the current situation, with this operationalised in line with the needs in each of the four nations.  It comes as Boris Johnson accepted a shock model suggesting , people were infected with Omicron yesterday and warned ministers a huge spike is coming. There have been long queues at walk-in vaccine centres as people rush to get their booster jabs before Christmas, while there have also been virtual queues as people try to access the booking system via the NHS website. The DHSC statement added: The CMOs recognise that this will lead to a marginal increase in risk for a very small number of people, but substantially fewer than would be harmed by a slower vaccine rollout in the current public health emergency leading to some citizens not getting boosted or vaccinated prior to exposure to Omicron.This includes a consideration that any prior vaccination and particularly boosting is likely to lessen the likelihood of severe disease arising from Omicron iant infection.  The Prime Minister held a virtual Cabinet meeting for the first time in months in light of the increasing number of Covid cases. Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty told ministers to expect a signicant increase in hospitalisations as cases rise, but it was too early to say how severe Omicron was, No said. Prof Whitty warned people could have to be turned away from hospitals by mid-January as a Covid wave engulfs hospital staff.  The UK Health Security Agencyhas estimated that the new iant was infecting , people a day as of yesterday. The shock figure is much higher than the recorded cases, which officials say is due to the speed at which the strain spreads and the delay in cases being picked up in official tests. Itaposs understood the , figure is only the mid range of modelling - so it could be even higher. With cases doubling every two to three days, it could theoretically lead to a million infections a day by next week. title: from now on catching covid
story: From now on, catching Covid means no Christmas for you amid Omicron confusionWith the prospect of further restrictions before the end of the year and a government leaving the public very much on their own, just how do we prepare for Christmas, asks Polly HudsonPM Boris Johnson has not ruled out further steps to control the Omicron outbreak Image: Getty ImagesopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Dec | comments Now we know what Boris Johnson meant when he said this festive season was going to be “considerably better” than last – that this year he won’t have to try to keep his Christmas parties quiet. No double meaning to Secret Santa this time, then.However, in one important way, this festive season is so far considerably worse than last, because back then we pretty much knew where we stood. It was going to be terrible – the end.This year, the present no one wanted: a massive heap of uncertainty. Oh Omicron, you shouldn’t have.It’s yet another twist on the Corona-coaster. Today is December ... crunch time. If you get infected from now on, your -day isolation will mean no Christmas for you. And perhaps a ripple effect of scrambled plans for othersyou are were meant to be hosting. So what to do  Or rather, what not to  Because while there will be some who no longer pay attention to a word that comes out of the Prime Minister’s mouth regarding restrictions, I believe they will be the minority. We can all see where they’re coming from, relate to their fury, but the reason I wear a mask is not because Boris Johnson told me to. It’s because it’s clearly necessary. One of the jigsaw pieces that will mean this is over faster, and we can start to put ourselves back together again. Most people want to do – will do – the right thing. The problem at the moment is that it’s very dficult to know what that is.Should we be going to our office Christmas parties while we’re working from home  Attending football matches, and other big, potentially superspreading sporting events like the World Darts Championship at Alexandra Palace  Popping round to the neighbours for mince pies  Having drinks with friends  Going to carol services, or even our kids’ nativity plays  In fact, should we be sending our children to school at all, seeing as there are outbreaks in most of them now  Omicron’s timing is perfect for messing our lives up as much as possible – close enough to Christmas to put an enormous question mark of doom over it, but not so early that the experts working round the clock know enough to make a final judgement. Make no mistake – we are very much on our own here. We’re going to have to work out the rules for ourselves. These rules will, presumably, y between us, just as our approaches to Covid have throughout the pandemic, from one extreme to another the cautious to the caution-to-the-wind-ers, and everyone  on the spectrum in-between. Now you have to hope your thinking matches up with anyone you were planning to see, and also try not to worry about the implications of mixing with people whose strategies have opposed yours up until now. Will you only spend Christmas with people who’ve had their booster  Insist on aclause that it must have been two weeks ago, so it’s kicked in  Make negative tests a condition of entry Maybe you’re tempted to admit defeat and cancel the whole thing, focus on having a great one next year instead… just like we did last year.The bitter reality is that we desperately need this Christmas to be exactly what it now cannot be – simple, peaceful, normal .Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CoronavirusCoronavirus vaccineBoris JohnsonOmicron iantChristmasChristmas DayChristmas partyTory Government" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics what-happened-asked--people-"Europe Talks : Group discusses the question ‘Was Brexit worth it ’ByMaryam QaiserFeatures WriterClaire DonnellyRos Wynne Jones:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsItaposs almost two years since Britain left the European Union, and a year since the transition agreement ended, yet feelings about it are still running high for many.So “Was Brexit worth it ” We put that question to  people and two moderators for Europe Talks as they sat on a moving artwork.Arist Jenny Brockman’s Seat # requires co-operation to keep everyone balanced. Thomas Kielinger, , is explaining why he thinks many Europeans regret Brexit. “It’s about the UK’s soft power,” says the Polish-born German who lives in London. “The language, pop culture, music, history, Shakespeare. That’s the predominant reason why Germans are so unhappy about Brexit, because they love Britain sometimes more than Brexiteers love Britain.” To join, see mirror europetalks  Entrepreneur and Brexiteer Saadia Baber, , of High Wycombe, Bucks, disagrees. “Just because I’m not in the EU, I am still part of Europe. We should be proud of the common human values we have.” The chat, hosted by the Goethe Institut in London, was screened to thousands of people across  countries. We discussed topics such as homelessness, EU migrants, sovereignty, empty shelves, flag-waving, imperialism and busking. Fortunately, nobody stormed off the seat and sent us all flying. And towards the end, even vehemently opposed Brexiteers and Remainers found a little common ground.“A lot of us have described ourselves as patriotic and loving our country,” said -year-old Labour councillor Jon-Conor Lyons, from Manchester.“I certainly want to believe in our country and I love Britain. I identy as a Manc, a Briton and a European.” View the full -minute video of the conversation on Vimeo Gosia Cabaj said the UK leaving the EU might have benefited Europe in one way, as it convinced many of her fellow Poles to stay in. Thomas said: “Now you are out of the EU, you only have yourself to blamethings don’t succeed.” Ada Pratt, a retired nursing sister from Rochdale who voted Leave, concluded with: “I think in general, everyone should stop blaming everybody  and talk to one another.” Ada, Jon-Conor, Saadia and Gosia were joined on Seat # by academic Ananya Jahanara Kabir, , Cambridge student Jovan Nepaul, , hotel worker Gisella Sobarasua, , from Nottingham, The New European journalist John Kampfner, and Express political editor David Maddox.  The debate was hosted by the Mirror and the Goethe Institut’s Katharina von Ruckteschell-Katte and screened in a live broadcast from Warsaw, Madrid, Berlin and London to celebrate this year’s Europe Talks. Over the last few weeks, , people, including , from the UK have been matched with people from dferent European countries for a videocall chat. Here are some of the people who met, and how they got on. Michael Bailey and Joan Willson When Brexiteer grandma Joan Willson met Michael Bailey - a former British citizen now living in Austria - the conversation quickly turned to Covid jabs and migration. Speaking at home in Camarthen, west Wales, Joan, , says: “You’re in the luckier spot in Austria – here in Wales, it is a total, utter disaster. We can’t see a doctor and I had a nightmare to get my booster.” Michael, , a translator, says: “I got my two jabs within five weeks of each other and I was literally able to walk in to get my booster.” He asks: “Would it worry youI said I am an immigrant in Austria ”  Joan, who lived in South Africa with her late husband, says: “I have no problem with that, we migrated to South Africa for a better le. We voted for the Conservatives because they had a promise that they would control immigration, but they haven’t. We don’t have jobs for our young people.” Michael says he “begs to dfer” and has helped an Afghan man who “has been through hell”. Angela Gash and Semra Gyokche When Angela Gash, , met Semra Gyokche, , an accountant living in Kardzhali, Bulgaria, she was pleased by Semra’s liberal attitudes. Accountant Angela, from Highbury, North London, said: “The general feeling we have been given about Eastern Europeans is that they can be homophobic and racist.  “I was so happy to see your responses.” Semra, who has gay friends, says, “Everyone is entitled to express themselves as they wish.” Angela went on: “% of us do want to be part of Europe. When we found out we were leaving Europe, I cried.” Semra agrees, adding. “When I came to the UK for a holiday, a lady said to us, ‘we don’t want the Romanians and Bulgarians here.” “I am so sorry you experienced that,” says Angela. Rich O’Mara and Maybritt Langewand Lockdown, the environment and languages were talking points when Rich O’Mara, , chatted to German student Maybritt Langewand, . Living in Wilmslow, Cheshire, with his we and kids, pilot Rich has been to Germany about  times but has struggled to learn the native tongue. He is due to make his first flight in two years and Madrid-based Maybritt has also been hit by the lockdown. The multi-linguist reveals: “University continued online but my mum suffered because we live off tourism. “I worry about our environment”. Rich says: “To be able to fly across Europe for £ is just wrong. There should be a minimum price that reflects its carbon cost.” Maybritt adds: “If you just raise the price, fewer people will use it, but you just exclude people who can’t pay.” Maria Hearl and Sevda Pumova Retired headteacher and vicar Maria Hearl has had pen pals since she was a teenager and jumped at the chance to update the tradition. When she joined a videocall with Sevda Pumova, an accountant, from Pleven, Bulgaria, their conversation came easily. Now they plan to keep in touch with fortnightly Zoom calls. Maria, who lives with her husband in Tiverton, Devon, loves travelling and when she reveals she’s visited Bulgaria, Sevda is impressed. The keen linguist says: “I’ve stayed not very far from where she lives and I’ve got a few phrases in Bulgarian. “The day we left Europe was the worst day of my le.” Sevda, , adds: “I love talking to Maria, she is very opinionated on most things. On most of it we found we have the same position.” Eddy Canfor-Dumas and Sigrid Korner Le after Brexit was the major topic of conversation when Brit Eddy Canfor-Duman got together with Sigrid Korner, , a university lecturer from Frankfurt, Germany, “There is a growing regret, people were lied to,” Eddy says. “There were two Leave campaigns. Farage and co, he appealed to a xenophobic, Little Britain. Then there was the libertarian side that talked about democracy and trade deals.” The -year-old writer from near Watford, adds: “There’s going to be huge buyers’ remorse.” “We were disappointed,” says Sigrid. “We were hoping until the last moment you would remain.” How both countries welcome migrants is another discussion with Sigrid feeling it’s positive although the “German reserve” means the people don’t mingle and stay in their own communities. Eddy adds: “My experience of Germany has been that it’s a much more tolerant society than Britain.” The pair agree to stay in touch. story: Brit gran, , to spend Christmas between the sheets with Egyptian toyboy, Iris Jones, , who is married to her -year-old Egyptian toyboy, has revealed more secrets about their sex le by saying that they plan to spend Christmas Day "between the sheets"Iris Jones, , said she will be spending Christmas Day between the sheets Image: bnmByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsAn -year-old grandmother who is married to her -year-old Egyptian toyboy has said she plans a Christmas Day “between the sheets”. Iris Jones has never been shy of talking about her sex le with her husband Mohamed, who is  years younger than her. She has said in the past that her husband is her pharaoh and has shared graphic details of the coupleaposs sex le - admitting she loves shocking people. Having married in November, , they were separated for almost a year as the Home Office sought proof of their relationship and his finances before giving him a spousal visa. Now with Mohamed having finally moved into her Weston-Super-Mare bungalow last month, the couple are keen to make up for lost time.Iris even told Closer magazine about their saucy plans for Christmas.On Christmas Day, Mohamed and I will just stay in bed, she said. Iris said they had no plans for giving presents as they “already have everything they want” but they may stop to listen to the Queen. She added: Weaposll have cheese on toast followed by mince pies and whipped cream, which Iaposll eat off his body - Iaposve never done that before.Weaposll take a break to watch The Queenaposs speech but other than that, youaposll find us between the sheets. Iris met Mohamed thanks to her son Stephen signing her up to Facebook and she joined a group for atheists where the Egyptian was also a member.Iris said she was impressed from the start with his good looks and intelligence. While she never imagined at the start that any romance would happen, Iris said how they started falling in love and then in November, , five months after connecting online, she flew to Cairo to meet him. Confident that it would all work out, she even packed her wedding dress. On that trip though they weren’t able to get married as his orce papers hadn’t come through and so they had to wait until her third trip to tie the knot in October . back to being a small child, you may remember how important your drawings were to you. When you get older, your scribbles as a child hold a lot of sentimentality - and one doting dad found the perfect way to preserve them. James Dickinson, , decided to have the drawings inked onto his leg - in order to immortalise it forever. He visited the tattoo studio Northside Tattooz, in Newcastle Upon Tyne armed with a carefully chosen selection of drawings - and artist Kara Chambers artfully brought it to le. It just seemed a better idea than getting names they are s**t hot little drawings they’ve done, and I thought that theyaposd make for a badass tattoo. “I felt really good at the sitting. Me and Kara are friends and I trusted her completely to put her artistic spin onto the drawings the kids have done. They just see it as I’ve got a drawing they’ve done on my leg. “When they’re older they’ll fully grasp it, taking in the meaning behind it more I’m sure.” Proud artist Kara, , from Newbiggan, who works at Northside Tattooz, added: “I was absolutely chuffed with the tattoo when it was finished. title: discontinued chocolate box staples miss
story: Discontinued chocolate box staples we miss most – from Dreams to Galaxy trufflesHeroes, Quality Street, Roses, and Celebrations have changed their chocolate line-ups over the years – but which axed choccies will you be missing this Christmas A total of  chocolates have been discontinued across the four big selection brands Image: Manchester Evening NewsByLuke WeirZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Dec | commentsOne of the best things about Christmas is the guilt-free gorging on food, especially sweet treats like chocolate. Almost all of us will be tucking into a selection box of choccies this festive season, and while every family have their favourite brand, the big four remain the same - Heroes, Quality Street, Roses, and Celebrations. But for those of us old enough to remember the ious chocolates that used to be in each of the selections, chomping on the newer line-ups just doesn’t feel the same. Whether it’s the white chocolate Dream bars that used to be in Heroes boxes, the coffee cremes from Roses, or my personal favourite, the Galaxy truffles that were removed from Celebrations – we all have that one flavour we just can’t get our hands on anymore. Surrey Live has compiled a list of all  flavours of chocolate that have been removed from the big four selection boxes over the years – but which one will you be missing the most this Christmas Quality Street Tins of Quality Street have been around since , and with an impressive -year history, it’s unsurprising the chocolates included in the box have changed. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. If you bought a tin this year, you’ll be tucking into classics including The Purple One, The Green Triangle, and Toffee Penny – but did you know there used to be some more interesting inclusions  Back in the day, you used to be able to get flavours like Gooseberry Cream and Apricot Delight which have been removed completely, while other chocolates such as the traditional Purple Onehave been changed over time. The list of discontinued or altered Quality Street chocolates include:Purple OneChocolate Strawberry CreamChocolate Toffee CupHazelnut Cracknell Hazelnut Eclair Honeycomb crunch Chocolate Nut Toffee Cream Malt Toffee Milk Chocolate RoundPeanut Cracknell Almond Octagon Gooseberry Cream Fig Fancy Apricot Delight Toffee Square Chocolate Truffle Montelimar Nougat Harrogate Toffee Fruits of the Forest Creme Smarties Coffee Cream Mint Fondant Toffee Deluxe Crispy Truffle BiteCelebrations Introduced by Mars in , Celebrations feature miniature versions of the favourite chocolate brands owned by the company, including Snickers, Galaxy, and Bounty.  Mars chocolates have been such a staple of the past  years that not much as changed in Celebrations boxes – with only two alterations being made to the original  line-up. Those flavours are:Galaxy Truffle TopicPersonally, the loss of Galaxy truffles in  was devastating – and I would love to see them make a ! Heroes  The much-loved Cadbury’s box of chocolates was introduced in  to rival boxes of Celebrations with the company’s own version of mini branded bars. When you tuck into this tin at Christmas time you’ll be feasting on the likes of Wispa, Creme Egg Twisted, and Crunchie – but did you know you used to be able to eat chunks of Dream white chocolate and Picnic  The eight chocolates to have lost their spot in the box are:Bournville Dairy Milk Whole Nut Dream Fuse Picnic Time Out Toblerone Nuts About CaramelRoses Another Cadbury’s classic, Roses was one of the original two boxes of chocolates to launch in the UK back in  – two years after Quality Street made its way onto the market.  And since Roses don’t take their flavours from existing Cadbury brands, the boxes have undergone far more changes than their sister box, Heroes. Currently, a box of Roses will include tasty treats such as Strawberry Dream and Country Fudge, but today’s tins are lacking in fallen flavours including Turkish Delight, Coffee Creme, and Lime Barrel. The missing chocolates from  Roses boxes are:Brazilian Darkness Praline Moment Chunky Truffle BournvilleAlmond Charm Coffee Creme Montelimar Marzipan Turkish Delight Nutty Truffle Log Orange Crisp Chocolate Bite Noisette Whirl Lime Barrel Black Cherry Cream Caramel Velvet Almond Caramel Bite Which chocolate flavours would you like to see make a   Let us know in the comments below. news uk-news expert-reveals-four-main-omicron-"Coronavirus: Tim Spector discusses Omicron symptomsByAdam ChapmanKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments An expert has revealed four of the main symptoms of the Omicron iant, as , new Covid- cases were confirmed in the UK in a single day - the highest rate of infection since January. The Omicron iant today becoming the dominant iant in London, and the government has introduced a raft of new measures in an attempt to curb the spread of the iant, including introducing daily testing for everyone who has come into contact with a positive case.The first UK cases of Omicron were only confirmed on November  and the speed of its spread has alarmed ministers and prompted a dramatic acceleration of the booster jab programme. Got a story  Email webnews@mirror  The UK Health Security Agency has previously projected that Omicron could become the dominant iant across the country by the middle of the month. So far one person is confirmed to have died from the Omicron iant - but their age or vaccination status isnapost known.The ZOE Covid app, which logs submissions from millions of users across the UK, has begun to hint at the iantaposs ability to evade vaccine-induced antibodies, the Express reports.Tim Spector, Professor of Genetic Epidemiology at King’s College London, who heads up the ZOE Covid study app, explained the symptoms being reported in those double or triple jabbed. A regular ZOE user entertained a th birthday party gathering with  guests, he told Good Morning Britain. All of them had taken lateral flow tests prior to the gathering. On Sunday they were informed that one of the guests - who happened to be a teacher - had tested positive and the following week  out of  had fallen ill in some way.  They were subsequently informed by NHS test and trace that it was Omicron or probable Omicron and they were waiting to get the genetic sequencing confirmations. According to the professor, the symptoms they reported were pretty mild.Quite a few of them had nausea, slight temperature, sore throats and headaches, he said.Although nobody was bad enough to need a doctor or go to hospital, all had been double and triple vaccinated, added Prof Spector. The fact that none of the cases required medical assistance indicates that the vaccines clearly reduced the severity of the illness, he noted. It now appears the current wave will result in a far higher peak amid warnings that Omicron cases could reach as high as one million a day. NHS England have scrapped the -minute wait for patients after theyaposve have their Pfizer Covid jabbed to speed up the booster programme.They have done away with the quarter-of-an-hour sit-down so more doses can be administered.  The isolation rules have also changed, with those who have come into contact with a positive case expected to do a daily lateral flow test. But todayaposs stats arrive after it emerged no PCR Covid test slots are left in areas of England today.Hertfordshire, Suffolk, the Isle of Wight, Bristol, and Mendip currently have no PCR tests - the gold standard of coronavirus tests - available to the general public at walk-in and drive-in test sites.The governments booking site previously said there are none available at every region in England while some slots are still available at sites in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. The site has since been updated with most areas having slots available again.Meanwhile, a decision on whether to vaccinate children as young as five could come in the next  days, the head of the UKaposs vaccine advisory group has said.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CoronavirusOmicron iant" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: family eight living sewage wrecked
story: Family-of-eight living in sewage-wrecked home haven’t been able to shower for weeksSam Hardy, the dad of a family-of-eight living in Portsmouth, Hampshire, claims his young children are becoming ill with constant sickness and diarrhea and that he has concerns about his pregnant we and unborn childDad-of-six Sam Hardy fears for his familys safety due to the sewage flooding his bottom floorByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA dad-of-six living in a home flooded with sewage claims the local council have refused to fix the issue and the large family have been unable to shower for six weeks. The bathroom of the Hardysapos three-bedroom house has been locked off since the start of November, when waves of poo and sewer waste started bursting up through the toilet into their property. In addition to the sewage, the home is infested with rodents that gnaw through their kitchen cupboards and also poo everywhere. Concerned dad Sam, , says his young children, aged between one and nine, are becoming chronically ill with sickness and diarrhoea. He is also anxious about his -week pregnant partner Rachel, and the health of his unborn seventh child. Mum Rachel says the family havenapost been able to shower or bathe for six weeks. She said the council promised a fix on Friday, but that nothing was resolved and my kids have to without a wash even longer. The council has since said it has visited the property and it was awaiting confirmation the drain had been unblocked. Rachel told The Sun : They just donapost care about us, they see us as scum, but we are desperate.My kids deserve better and shouldnapost have to live like this, and Sam and I constantly feel stressed and depressed. With no other options, the couple have had to fill up a small bath, which is designed for babies, with a kettle in order to wash the kids and themselves. For four hours yesterday, they plunged their bare hands into the drain to unblock it, because a maintenance worker failed to do so, they claim. When itaposs time to wash in the tiny makesht bath, Rachel lays blankets on the kitchen floor, but says the family shouldnapost have to do so in the modern age. A nine-year-old should not be washing in a baby bath. This is , not , she adds. Sam claims the council are refusing to help the family, and heaposs had enough of dealing with them.Sam, from Southsea in Portsmouth, Hampshire, said: My kids shouldnapost have to live like this.The sewage is squirting out from the downstairs toilet all over the floor. Every time we use the shower or flush the toilet upstairs, the toilet downstairs will start filling up and sewage will start spewing over and coming out of dferent pipes. Sam says there is an outdoor drain thataposs also blocked and leaking sewage. On top of having to constantly clear the home and garden of fecal matter and toilet roll, the home is also infested with mice. Every single night the couple wake up to find the mice have plundered the kitchen, and nibbled through the cupboards and shelves. Sam claims the council hasnapost lted a finger to help despite the issue continuing for nearly two months. He believes itaposs because he owes the council £, which heaposs steadily repaying, after a benefit change. And he claims the council have told him that they will help once he repays his outstanding debt. The couple got social services, their midwe, and the kidaposs school to write to the council, but they havenapost done anything except asking for their money.  The horric living conditions have left the couple suffering with depression and anxiety as they feel trapped and hopeless. They claim the kids, aged one, three, four, five, six and nine, are visiting the doctors often with conditions they link to the situation. In a desperate attempt to find out whataposs wrong with them, they even phone  because we were so worried. But  told them itaposs unlikely it will be the mice and sewage. A spokesperson for Portsmouth City Council told The Mirror: Council officers attended the property on Wednesday last week and an order was raised for a drain to be unblocked on Friday.  We are waiting for confirmation that the drain was unblocked. We will also be helping the tenants clear the front and rear gardens, treat for mice and carry out any other repairs that are required. In a separate statement shared to The Sun, the council said they are not withholding any services from the family and have made several visits to the home. They claimed to have taken appropriate action, and that they werenapost notied about sewage at the property. The council added that a housing officer will be in touch with tenants and visit to investigate the situation. news uk-news five-missed-chances-save-star-"Star Hobson: West Yorkshire Police release  callByLucy Thornton:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec  At least five members of Frankie Smith’s extended family made independent referrals to social services about their fears for her daughter, Star Hobson, , with one being told: “She is safe in the hands of her mother”.Hollie Jones, , babysat Star so often the toddler called her ‘mum’ .She went to social services about bruising on Star and domestic violence by Savannah Brockhill on Frankie. The teenager was the first to make a referral on January , , and told The Mirror: “I was worried the way Star changed after Frankie met Savannah. She just changed.“Frankie would leave her in a baby walker on the carpet all day. She was still giving her baby milk at  months old.  “I telephoned social services, and I was with Frankie and Star when social services rang her to tell her they were coming to see her in an hour. I thought it was a bit stupid, as it was like ringing a criminal and telling them they are going to come round and arrest them in an hour. “Frankie spent the whole hour cleaning and tidying the house, we were at her mum Yvonne’s and getting Star all nicely sorted, covering up bruises. “In the end it was two police officers that arrived, not social workers. I was holding Star and they spoke to Frankie. I think social services tried to see Frankie again but she was not at home. “I later got a telephone call from social services telling me they are closing the case because Star is ‘safe in the hands of her mother. “I honestly feel quite gutted about the jury’s verdict on Frankie, I thought she should have been found guilty of manslaughter. I’m happy that Star has got some justice and really happy Savannah was found guilty of murder. But social services should have done more.” Hollie said she felt “really angry” and that “social services need to step up more” adding: “I’m just really gutted because I think changes really need to be made becausethey took my referral seriously, potentially Star wouldn’t be gone.” In February Frankie and Brockhill split and Star went to live with her great grandparents until the end of April because her mum was ‘struggling’. On May th, Frankie’s grandmother Anita Smith referred her granddaughter to social services after another relative told her Brockhill had been ‘slam choking’ Star. Together with her partner David Fawcett, the great grandmother looked after Star for ten weeks when Frankie couldn’t cope. Frankie managed to persuade them her grandmother’s report was ‘malicious’ because she was in a same-sex relationship with a ‘gypsy’. She then banned her grandmother from seeing Star and social services closed the case without informing Anita. In June Alicia Szepler, Smith’s sister and Star’s aunt, sends photographs of bruises to the police and speaks to officers. On June st, Star’s student father, Jordan Hobson, also made a referral to social services after he was sent a photo of his daughter’s bruised face. Police again visited their home and saw the markings on the baby’s head. This was the third referral.  Police, along with a social services representative, took Frankie and Star to Bradford Royal Infirmary that day, but she was seen by a doctor with only four months’ experience in child safely who saw the injuries in isolation and accepted the excuses that the toddler had bumped into a coffee table knob and hurt her leg playing with a puppy. On June rd Rachel Whiteley, a friend of Frankie’s mother, made a social services referral after observing her behaviour at a family barbecue. But  days later social services closed the case. On September nd, Frank Smith, Star’s paternal great-grandfather, made a social services referral after seeing a video of bruises on the infant’s face. Social services visited Frankie but were told she was in Scotland. On an unannounced visit next day, when Frankie was present with Brockhill, social workers observed the flat was clean, tidy and warm. They found a faint bruise to Star’s cheek and a bruise on her right shin. Star was unsteady on her feet and walked into a sofa while social services were present. Frankie said Star had fallen down the stairs. Social services closed the case on September th after the social worker concluded the referral was malicious.  Although the final referral was closed on th September, social services were still in contact with Frankie Smith right up until the day of Star’s death. Smith was due to meet the social worker on September nd, the day Star was murdered, but the meeting was put off for three days. The social worker sent a text to Smith to say: “Thanks for letting me know, we will do Friday at .am.”  Robbie Moore, Tory MP for Keighley and Ilkley, has called for the resignation of Susan Hinchclfe and the council’s chief executive Kersten England in the light of the Star Hobson case. He said: “Bradford Council bosses should hang their heads in shame. I have no confidence children’s services will ever be fit for purpose under its current leadership. “I am afraid it is my view that Council Leader Susan Hinchclfe and Chief Executive Kersten England must resign.” Read MoreRead MoreFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON MurderSocial servicesSocial workersCrimeDomestic violenceStar HobsonChild abuse" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Im facing first Christmas without my son after doctors just thought he had stressRiley Gregersen, nine, suffered a seizure at school in January after struggling with holding his arm steady and writing at school, and his parents were given the devastating news their son had an incurable brain tumour.Mum Gemma is facing her first Christmas without Riley Gregersen, nine, who died of a brain tumour Image: Brain Tumour Research   SWNSByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA mum has spoke of her heartache at spending her first Christmas without her son, who died of a brain tumour after doctors told them his symptoms could have been stress. Riley Gregersen, nine, was a typical young boy who loved playing football with his friends, but alarm bells began to be rung when he began to struggle with with his writing. Teachers attributed it to mental health problems, but when his terried parents took him to doctors they suggested it could be down to stress or even a trapped nerve. Within weeks, his arm began to shake uncontrollably meaning he couldnapost even feed himself. Got a story  Email webnew@mirror  Blood tests didnapost show anything concerning, but Riley was rushed to hospital after suffering a seizure during an after school club. His parents Gemma and Scott were given the devastating news that their son had an aggressive brain tumour called glioblastoma multorme . Due to where the tumour was, surgeons could only remove around % and the surgery was highly dangerous. His family raised funds for treatment in Germany but tragically the cancer spread to his spine and he was admitted to a hospice where he died on August . Now facing her first Christmas without Riley, the family have bravely spoken out in a bid to warn parents to be aware of the symptoms of brain tumours in children.  Gemma, , from Stourbridge, West Mids., said: Riley loved everything about Christmas and I have so many special memories to cherish. Every year he would sit with the Smyths Toys catalogue and tell me everything he wanted. He loved to pick out presents and write cards for his friends too he was such a kind and generous boy. Iaposll never forget the huge smile on his face when I would take his photo in front of our Christmas tree, it was the best thing ever. Riley always wanted to help people. After he died, so many people told me about how caring he was. Rileyaposs health initially went down hill just before Christmas  when he struggled to hold his pen at school and Gemma took him to their GP. Gemma, who is no longer with Scott, said: They said his symptoms were stress-related, or possibly a trapped nerve. We were sent away and told to come back in a few weeksapos time for a blood test,he was no better, which we did. Rileyaposs teachers also noticed his tremor was causing him to struggle to write and they contacted Gemma to say they were worried about his mental health.  Gemma, an admin assistant, added: I assured them that Riley had a happy home le and no reason to be feeling anxious or stressed. When the results from the blood tests came back, they didnapost reveal anything of concern, so Riley was referred for an aposurgentapos MRI scan but the appointment didnapost come through before he suffered the seizure on  January. Rileyaposs prognosis remained stark, so Gemma and Scott began researching alternative treatment options overseas. They found a private clinic in Germany which made peptide vaccines which could extend Rileyaposs le at a cost of £,. Despite a fundraising drive, Riley became too ill and in May doctors delivered the heartbreaking news that the cancer had spread. Gemma said: Things had been going so well when, in May, Riley started complaining of numbness in his legs and he had balance issues.  He was having problems going to the toilet, even though he was drinking a lot. I called for an ambulance and they took us into Birmingham Childrenaposs Hospital. They did another MRI scan and when got the results, my world fell apart.The tumour had spread and four new tumours had appeared on his spine. There was very little they could do.Riley had more palliative radiotherapy but after that, there were no other treatments available. The German clinic sent Rileyaposs vaccines to the UK, as he was unable to travel, but Gemma couldnapost find anyone in the country willing to administer the vaccine because it was not certied by the NHS.She said: It was completely shattering. At .pm on  August, my precious boy died in my arms. Even though I knew it was coming, it was an absolute shock and just so hard to comprehend.One thing I am pleased to do this Christmas is to share our story to help raise awareness, in the hope that I can help to make a dference, in Rileyaposs name.Brain tumours kill more children and adults under the age of  than any other cancer in the UK. story: Le support treatment to end for most complicated Covid patient in worldThe grandmother, who is in her fties, has been left brain-damaged and permanently paralysed, and while her family says she should be given more time, a judge has ruled that le-support treatment can endA judge has ruled that the le-support of a British grandmother should be stopped despite her family wanting it to continue Image: Geoff Robinson Photography REX ShutterstockByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Dec | comments A judge has ruled that the le-support of a British grandmother who was hospitalised with coronavirus should be stopped despite her family wanting it to continue.The woman in her fties has been described by doctors as the most complicated Covid patient in the world, and has been left brain-damaged and paralysed from the neck down after contracting the virus. Specialists treating the woman at Addenbrookeaposs Hospital in Cambridge, had told a judge that le-support treatment should end, despite her familyaposs insistence she should be given more time. The patient, described only as AH in court papers, has not been publicly named to protect her privacy. Mrs Justice Theis has now ruled that le-support treatment can end, and that the woman can be allowed to die, after reconsidering arguments.  Last week, she examined up-to-date evidence at a hearing in the Court of Protection, where issues relating to people who lack the mental capacity to make decisions are considered, over two days in London. Another judge had originally considered the case at a hearing in the Court of Protection in August. Mr Justice Hayden also concluded that le-support treatment should end and ruled that the woman should be allowed to die. The womanaposs adult children challenged his ruling in the Court of Appeal. Appeal judges upheld their challenge and said the case should be reheard - Mrs Justice Theis then oversaw a second Court of Protection trial.  Relatives told Mrs Justice Theis that in the past four months they had seen a bubblier person and someone who was more alert and aware.But specialists treating her said she had deteriorated since August.The news comes as the UK faces a new challenge in dealing with the Omicron iant, and as new rules for testing come into force. Anyone who has come into contact with a Covid- case must now use a lateral flow test for seven days instead of isolating - although they are not available on the government website. The government insisted on Monday that there was no shortage of kits as aposample suppliesapos exist it shops. Yet on Tuesday morning a new message on the gov.uk website said ,  and  did not have access to any more tests - as well as none being available for home deliveries. Boris Johnson reiterated that home test kits were available at pharmacies when he was challenged over the message on the website.He said: They can get those tests, we do have a ready supply of lateral flow tests. If you canapost get one online for any reason, then there are ample supplies in the shops. But what I think,I may say so, what that also shows is that people are doing the sensible thing, and getting tests as well.On Monday, the UK Health Security Agency said that due to exceptionally high demand, ordering lateral flow tests on gov.uk has been temporarily suspended to fulfil existing orders. It also was revealed today that there are no PCR Covid test slots left available anywhere across England.The government website says there are no PCR tests - the gold standard of coronavirus tests - available to the general public at walk-in and drive-in test sites across the country.The booking site said there are none available at every region in England while some slots are still available at sites in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. PCR test kits which are posted to peopleaposs homes, usually arriving the following day, are available, the website claims. The public are being advised to try again laterthey cannot get a test. Tests will not be available through helplines, the website added. story: Mum baffled by drivers sorry note saying not giving details as your car is s**tSarah Hall ed to her car parked at Market Place in Ramsbottom, Greater Manchester, on Tuesday morning to find the note which followed an apology with an insult about her carSarah Hall said she was furious with the mystery driver Image: MEN MEDIAByEmma Gill:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA mum says she was left baffled by a note left on her car from a fellow driver calling her car s**t. Sarah Hall ed to her car parked at Market Place in Ramsbottom, Greater Manchester, on Tuesday morning to find a note saying: Sorry hit your car. But not giving my details as your car is s**t.They even signed off the baffling note with have a nice day, merry Christmas and happy new year, reports the Manchester Evening News.Sarah, from Radclfe, Bury, says she canapost even see any damage to her Suzuki Celerio, which she found with the mirrors pushed in and window wipers pulled out - apart from the one holding the note. The mum-of-two, who works at Cohens Chemist close to Market Place, shared a photo of the note on Facebook in a plea to find whoever was responsible for the message which was left on her car.  My car is fine I’m just curious who did it  said Sarah, . My car is s**t but only I’m allowed to say that, she joked. All the mirrors were pushed in and wipers up, except the one that had the note on. story: Mum who gave birth during Covid coma pleased to be home with daughter for ChristmasLaura Ward has been counting down the days to her discharge date since waking from a seven-week coma to discover shed given birth to her daughter HopeLaura Ward said her husband, John, has been amazing Image: MEN MediaByEmma Gill:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec A mum who woke up from a Covid coma to find she had given birth has been released from hospital in time to spend Christmas at home with her new daughter.Laura Ward has been counting down the days to her discharge date sincewaking from a seven-week comato discover sheaposd given birth to her daughter Hope, more than two months before her due date. The mum had nodded to doctors to give consent to deliver Hope after medics told her they might have to deliver the baby early, although Laura said she has no recollection of this whatsoever,Manchester Evening News reports .I opened my eyes to see Hope on the bed with me, but I couldnapost move any part of my body, the -year-old said. All I could do was shake and nod my head. Laura, a teaching assistant, arrived at hospital struggling to breathe after being diagnosed with Covid at the beginning of the school summer holidays. Her condition deteriorated so much that she was sedated for an emergency C-section at  weeks and then put into a coma. It was only when Laura finally came round at the end of September - much to the relief of family and friends - that she realised her precious girl had arrived. Lauraaposs partner John Leece has been taking Hope for daily visits to see her mum in Trafford General, where sheaposs been undergoing intensive rehabilitation, including learning how to walk again. But after finally being allowed toto her home in Tyldesley, Wigan, sheaposs now been reunited with her family, including three-year-old son William and step-children Josh and Lexi. Family and friends, including her parents Lynn and Bill, were there to greet her as she arrived on Monday morning to a house decorated with balloons and aposwelcome homeapos posters. Iaposm so pleased to be home, said Laura, who had gestational diabetes throughout her pregnancy. The physiotherapist brought me home and John was there waiting for me with the kids. William was so excited he was shouting aposmummy, mummyapos and trying to get in the car.Itaposs been nearly five months since Laura was last at home, before she was initially treated at the Royal Bolton and later transferred to Wythenshawe Hospital, where she spent  days of her coma on an ECMO machine - the highest level of le support. John, , said he had aposevery faithapos that sheaposd have the strength to pull through. Iaposm ecstatic to have her back after all this time, he said. Itaposs been tough but weaposve had people helping us out and theyaposre all good kids so thataposs made it easier. The worst day was when they rang and said they needed to do an emergency C-section and then after that they said they needed to get her on one of the ECMO machines or  she could die. She met all the criteria, it was just a case of waiting to seethey had a bed. Once she was there we knew she was in the best place and I had every faith sheaposd pull through because sheaposd been fit and well before it. He added: I always had an inkling she would be coming home, just because of the person she is. She had her kids to come home for and a lot to fight for. After coming round from her coma, having had tracheostomy and feeding tubes fitted, it was two weeks before Laura was even able to speak and sheaposs since had to learn how to do the most basic things all over again. The muscles in her legs had deteriorated over the weeks and it was only at the beginning of December when she managed to walk again - firstly making her way down the hospital corridor with a frame and then holding the hand of her three-year-old son William. Lauraaposs physiotherapy will now continue at home and sheaposs been given ious support aids to help her around the house. For now sheaposll have a bed downstairs, but sheaposs already been tackling the stairs herself. I said to John when I got home that I just wanted to try them, she said. I did manage to get to the top but when I got there I needed to sit down and I needed help getting back up. Itaposll take some time but Iaposll get there. After a takeaway pizza night to celebrate her homecoming, the family are now looking forward to having a happy settled Christmas at home. Laura hopes toto her job at Tyldesley Primary School in September, when son William will also be starting there. And sheaposs been inundated with messages of support from parents and staff who canapost wait to have her back. title: revellers enjoy last night freedom
story: Revellers enjoy last night of freedom before Covid passes are needed at clubsRevellers have been hitting bars and nightclubs and having festive fun in fancy dress as they enjoy the final day of "freedom" before new Covid restrictions come in on WednesdayHundreds of people headed to a nightclub in Portsmouth on Tuesday night Image: Paul Jacobs pictureexclusiveByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsParty-goers dressed up as Father Christmases and other festive figures were in high spirits as they headed to crowded bars and nightclubs around the country to celebrate the last day of freedom before Covid passes are enforced. With many people in festive spirits they have been heading out to parties and drinks with friends before new restrictions are introduced in an attempt to slow the spread of the Omicron iant. In Portsmouth hundreds of people flocked to a themed night at the Astoria nightclub. People could be seen dressed up in their Christmas gear with plenty of Father Christmases and some snowmen on show. And it was not just Tuesday night as last weekend thousands were out in towns and cities for festive fun.  Little regard was taken for the highly contagious new Covid iant which is forcing the new rules from Wednesday. People will need to show that they have had two vaccine doses or a negative test in order to go into nightclubs and some other venues. The government has said that lateral flow tests should be used by people entering “high-risk settings like crowded places.  Nightclub owners have hit out at the new restrictions saying that a lack of rapid COVID- tests will make enforcement a big challenge.Last week, Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced his Plan B measures to tackle the spread of the Omicron iant.The UK has registered almost , cases of Omicron, with  people hospitalised and one person dying after contracting the iant.  New rules were passed in Parliament on Tuesday though  members of Johnsonaposs own party voted against them. Kate Fuller, who owns the Electric Ballroom nightclub in Camden in north London said the lack of available rapid testing is a problem for her. Since the announcement of the restrictions, our business just took a massive downturn, she said.  Thereaposs no testing in a lot of the pharmacies. If you canapost get the tests, itaposs going to be really hard for people to come. I think for our security and everything, implementing these is just going to be, you know, a big challenge. The new rules will apply to unseated indoor events with  people or more, unseated outdoor events with over , people and events with more than , attendees.  Clara Cullen, venue support manager at charity Music Venue Trust, which supports around  music venues in the country, said there had been an increase in cancellations with income falling by % in the past week. There will be financial implications to trying to implement the Plan B, said Cullen.
